tn.text: This is a new event; it is now the Day of Pentecost, 50 days after Passover.
Here the word "they" refers to the apostles and the other 120 believers that Luke mentions in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:15]].
This word refers to an event that happens unexpectedly.

tn.ref: there came from heaven a sound
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "heaven" refers to the place where God lives. AT: "a sound came from heaven" or 2) "heaven" refers to the sky. AT: "a sound came from the sky"

tn.ref: a sound like the rush of a violent wind
tn.text: "a noise that sounded like a very strong wind blowing"
This may have been a house or a larger building.

tn.ref: There appeared to them tongues like fire
tn.text: These might not be actual tongues or fire, but something that looked like them. Possible meanings are 1) tongues that looked like they were made of fire or 2) small flames of fire that looked like tongues. When fire burns in a small space, such as on a lamp, the flame can be shaped like a tongue. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: that were distributed, and they sat upon each one of them
tn.text: This means that the "tongues like fire" spread out so that there was one on each person.

tn.ref: They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Holy Spirit filled all of those who were there and they" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These are languages that they did not already know.
Verse 5 gives background information about the large number of Jews who were living in Jerusalem, many of whom were present during this event. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Here the word "them" refers to the believers; the word "his" refers to each person in the multitude.
Here "godly men" refers to people who were devout in their worship of God and tried to obey all of the Jewish laws.
"every nation in the world." This is an exaggeration that emphasizes that the people came from many different nations. AT: "many different nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This refers to the sound that was similar to a strong wind. AT: "When they heard this sound" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the large crowd of people"
These two words share similar meanings. Together they emphasize the intensity of amazement. AT: "They were greatly amazed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Really, are not all these who are speaking Galileans?
tn.text: The people ask this question to express their amazement. The question could be changed to an exclamation. AT: "All of these Galileans could not possibly know our languages!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: Why is it that we are hearing them, each in our own language in which we were born?
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is a rhetorical question that expresses how amazed they were or 2) this is a real question for which the people wanted an answer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: in our own language in which we were born
tn.text: "in our own languages that we have learned from birth"
This lists some of the many nations, regions, and cities from which they came. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"converts to the Jewish religion"
These two words share similar meanings. Together they emphasize that the people could not understand what was happening. AT: "surprised and confused" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: They are full of new wine
tn.text: Some people accuse the believers of having drunk too much wine. AT: "They are drunk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to wine that is in the process of fermentation.
Peter begins his speech to the Jews who were there on the Day of Pentecost.
All the apostles stood up in support of Peter's statement.

tn.ref: let this be known to you
tn.text: This means that Peter is about to explain the meaning of what the people had witnessed. This can be stated in active form. AT: "know this" or "let me explain this to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Peter was referring to what he was saying. AT: "listen carefully to what I am saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: it is only the third hour of the day
tn.text: "It is only nine o'clock in the morning" (UDB). Peter expected his audience to know that people do not get drunk that early in the day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here Peter tells them a passage about which the prophet Joel wrote in the Old Testament that relates to what is happening with the languages in which the believers spoke. This is written in the form of poetry as well as being a quotation.

tn.ref: this is what was spoken through the prophet Joel
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "this is what God told the prophet Joel to write" or "this is that which the prophet Joel spoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"This is what will happen" or "This is what I will do"

tn.ref: I will pour out my Spirit on all people
tn.text: Here the words "pour out" mean to give generously and abundantly. AT: "I will give my Spirit abundantly to all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Peter continues to quote the prophet Joel.

tn.ref: my servants and my female servants
tn.text: "both my male and my female servants." These words emphasize that God will pour out his Spirit on all of his servants, both men and women.

tn.ref: I will pour out my Spirit
tn.text: Here the words "pour out" mean to give generously and abundantly. AT: "I will give my Spirit abundantly to all people." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:16|2:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"thick smoke" or "clouds of smoke"
Peter finishes quoting the prophet Joel.

tn.ref: The sun will be turned to darkness
tn.text: This means that the sun will appear to be dark instead of light. AT: "The sun will become dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that the moon will appear to be red like blood. AT: "and the moon will appear to be red" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
The words "great" and "remarkable" share similar meanings and emphasize the intensity of greatness. AT: "the very great day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"unusual" or "important"

tn.ref: everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Lord will save everyone who calls on him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Peter continues his speech to the Jews that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]].
"listen to what I am about to say"

tn.ref: authenticated by God ... by mighty deeds and wonders and signs
tn.text: This means that God proved that he had appointed Jesus for his mission by having Jesus perform miracles.

tn.ref: a man authenticated by God to you
tn.text: "a man whom God authenticated to you"

tn.ref: because of the determined plan and foreknowledge of God
tn.text: This means that God planned out and knew beforehand what would happen to Jesus. AT: "because God planned out and knew beforehand everything that would happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Possible meanings: 1) "you handed Jesus over into the hands of his enemies" (UDB) or 2) "Judas betrayed Jesus to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: you, by the hand of lawless men, crucified and killed him
tn.text: Although "lawless men" actually crucified Jesus, Peter accuses the crowd of having killed him because they demanded his death.

tn.ref: by the hand of lawless men
tn.text: "by the means of lawless men," "by the authority of lawless men," or "by using lawless men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: having loosed the pains of death ... held by it
tn.text: Peter speaks of death as if it were a person who holds people prisoner and causes them to suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: having loosed the pains of death from him
tn.text: Peter speaks of death as if it ties people up with painful cords. AT: "having freed him from the pain that death causes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: that he should be held by it
tn.text: "that he should be held by death." This can be stated in active form. AT: "that death should hold him" or "that death should keep him in its power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here Peter quotes a passage that David wrote in a Psalm which relates to Jesus' crucifixion and resurrection.
Since Peter says that David said these words about Jesus, the words "I" and "my" refer to Jesus and the words "Lord" and "he" refer to God.
"in front of me." AT: "in my presence" or "with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

To be at someone's "right hand" often means to be in a position to help and sustain. AT: "right beside me" or "with me to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here the word "moved" means to be troubled. This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will not be able to cause me trouble" or "nothing will trouble me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced
tn.text: People consider the "heart" the center of emotions and the "tongue" voices those emotions. AT: "I was glad and rejoiced" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: my flesh will live in confidence
tn.text: Possible meanings of the word "flesh" are 1) he is a mortal who will die. AT: "Even though I am only mortal, I will have confidence in God" or 2) it is synecdoche for his entire person. AT: "I will live with confidence in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Peter finishes quoting David.
Since Peter says that David said these words about Jesus, the words "my," "Holy One," and "me" refer to Jesus and the words "you" and "your" refer to God.

tn.ref: neither will you allow your Holy One to see decay
tn.text: The Messiah, Jesus, refers to himself with the words "your Holy One." AT: "neither will you allow me, your Holy One, to see decay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here the word "see" means to experience something. The word "decay" refers to the decomposition of his body after death. AT: "to decay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the ways that lead to life"

tn.ref: full of gladness with your face
tn.text: Here the word "face" refers to the presence of God. AT: "very glad when I see you" or "very glad when I am in your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"joy" or "happiness"
Peter continues his speech that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]] to the Jews that surround him and the other believers in Jerusalem.
In verses 29 & 30, the words he," "his," and "him" refer to David. In verse 31, the first "He" refers to David and the words within the quote "He" and "his" refer to Christ.
"Fellow Jews"

tn.ref: he both died and was buried
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he died and people buried him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: he would set one of the fruit of his body upon his throne
tn.text: "God would set one of David's descendants upon David's throne." AT: "God would appoint one of David's descendants to be king in David's place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: one of the fruit of his body
tn.text: Here the word "fruit" refers to what "his body" produces. AT: "one of his descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"He knew this before it happened." Peter uses this language to speak of knowing something beforehand as if it were seen beforehand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In this case, God enabled David to speak about the Messiah's resurrection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He was neither abandoned to Hades
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God did not abandon him to Hades" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: nor did his flesh see decay
tn.text: Here the word "see" means to experience something. The word "decay" refers to the decomposition of his body after death. AT: "nor did his flesh decay" or "nor did he remain dead long enough for his flesh to decay." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:27|2:27]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "we" refers to the disciples and those that witnessed the risen Jesus after his death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here, the second word "this" refers to the disciples' speaking in other languages when they received the Holy Spirit.
Here the word "raised" refers to God's raising Jesus from the dead.

tn.ref: having been raised up to the right hand of God
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God having raised Jesus up to his right hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: having been raised up to the right hand
tn.text: This refers to God's exalting Jesus to a position of honor and authority.

Here the words "poured out" mean that Jesus who is God made these events to happen. It is implicit that he does this by giving the Holy Spirit to the believers. AT: "he has caused these things to happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here the words "pour out" mean to give generously and abundantly. AT: "given abundantly." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:16|2:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Peter finishes his speech to the Jews that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:01:15|1:16]].
Peter again quotes one of David's Psalms. David is not speaking of himself in this Psalm. "The Lord" and "my" refer to God; "my Lord" and "your" refer to Jesus the Messiah.

tn.ref: until I make your enemies the stool for your feet
tn.text: This means that God will completely defeat the Messiah's enemies and make them subject to him. AT: "until I make you victorious over all of your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the entire nation of Israel. AT: "every Israelite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The Jews respond to Peter's speech and Peter answers them.
Here the word "they" refers to the people in the crowd to whom Peter spoke.
"when the people heard what Peter had said"

tn.ref: they were pierced in their hearts
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Peter's words pierced their hearts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that the people felt guilty and became very sad. AT: "deeply troubled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "allow us to baptize you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: For to you is the promise
tn.text: "Because the promise is for you"
This means either 1) "all people who live far away" or 2) "all people who are far from God."

This is the end of the part of the story that happened on the Day of Pentecost.  Verse 42 begins a section that explains how the believers continued to live after the Day of Pentecost. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])

"he seriously told them and begged them." Here the words "testified" and "urged" share similar meanings and emphasize that Peter urged them strongly to respond to what he was saying. AT: "he strongly urged them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Save yourselves from this wicked generation
tn.text: The implication is that God will punish "this wicked generation." AT: "Save yourselves from the punishment that these wicked people will suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the word "received" means that they accepted what Peter said to be true. AT: "they believed what Peter said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "people baptized them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: there were added in that day about three thousand souls
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "about three thousand souls joined the believers on that day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "souls" refers to people. AT: "about 3,000 people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This means that they shared meals and ate together.

Here the word "Fear" refers to deep respect and awe for God. The word "soul" refers to the entire person. AT: "Each person felt a deep respect and awe for God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: many wonders and signs were done through the apostles
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "the apostles performed many wonders and signs" or 2) "God performed many wonders and signs through the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"miraculous deeds and supernatural events." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:22|2:22]].
Possible meanings are 1) "All of them believed the same thing" or 2) "All who believed were together in the same place."
"shared their belongings with one another"
"land and things they owned"
Here the word "them" refers to the profit that they made from selling their property and possessions. AT: "distributed the proceeds to all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: according to the needs anyone had
tn.text: They distributed the proceeds that they earned from selling their property and possessions to any believer who had a need.
Possible meanings are 1) "they continued meeting together" (UDB) or 2) "they all continued to have the same attitude."

Possible meanings are 1) "they shared their meals and ate together in their homes" or 2) "they celebrated the Lord's Supper together in their homes." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:40|2:42]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: with joy and humility of heart
tn.text: Here the word "humility" may refer to generosity. The word "heart" refers to the entire person. AT: "joyfully and generously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: had favor with all the people
tn.text: "all the people approved of them"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "those whom the Lord saved" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
